<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">33</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note8>Note 8. Changes in Capitalization</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In October 2008, PSEG paid $49 million of its 6.89% Senior Notes.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of September 30, 2008, 2,382,200 shares were repurchased at a total price of $92 million. In July 2008, the Board of Directors of PSEG authorized the repurchase of up to $750 million of PSEG Common Stock to be executed over 18 months beginning August 1, 2008. PSEG is not obligated to acquire any
  specific number of shares and may suspend or terminate its share repurchases at any time.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In September 2008, Power paid a cash dividend to PSEG of $225 million and in each of June 2008 and March 2008, Power paid a cash dividend to PSEG of $125 million.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In May 2008, PSE&amp;G redeemed its outstanding $157 million of 6.375% First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds Remarketable Series YY Due 2023 Mandatorily Tendered 2008. PSE&amp;G paid approximately $32 million in cash to settle the remarketing option held by the remarketing dealer.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In April 2008, PSE&amp;G issued $400 million of 5.30% Medium-Term Notes, Series E due May 1, 2018.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In March 2008, PSE&amp;G issued $300 million of Floating Rate (3-month Libor + 0.875%) Bonds due 2010.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of December 31, 2007, PSE&amp;G had $494 million of variable rate pollution control bonds outstanding which serviced and secured a like amount of insured tax-exempt variable rate bonds of the Pollution Control Authority of Salem County (Salem County Authority). Through April 2008, PSE&amp;G purchased $494
  million of the Salem County Authority bonds which were either being held by the broker/dealer or tendered by bondholders upon conversion of the bonds to a weekly interest rate mode. These purchases were recorded as a reduction to PSE&amp;G&#146;s Long-Term Debt included in its Condensed Consolidated Balance
  Sheets. PSE&amp;G intends to hold these bonds until they can be remarketed or refinanced.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In September 2008, June 2008 and March 2008, Transition Funding repaid $45 million, $37 million and $40 million, respectively, of its transition bonds.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In June 2008, PSE&amp;G Transition Funding II LLC repaid $5 million of its transition bonds.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In March 2008, Energy Holdings repurchased $5 million of its $530 million then outstanding 8.50% Senior Notes due 2011.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In February 2008, Energy Holdings repaid at maturity $207 million of its 8.625% Senior Notes.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In January 2008, Energy Holdings redeemed its outstanding $400 million of 10% Senior Notes due 2009.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During the first nine months of 2008, Energy Holdings paid $48 million in premiums related to the early redemption of its outstanding debt.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During the first nine months of 2008, Energy Holdings&#146; subsidiaries repaid $38 million of non-recourse debt, primarily related to the PSEG Texas generation facilities.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">34</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>

<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note9>Note 9. Other Income and Deductions</a></B></FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%;" >
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD style="width:62.02%;"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:4.71%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:6.01%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:7.66%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:9.60%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>

<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note10>Note 10. Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits (OPEB)</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG sponsors several qualified and nonqualified pension plans and OPEB plans covering PSEG&#146;s and its participating affiliates&#146; current and former employees who meet certain eligibility criteria. The following table provides the components of net periodic benefit costs relating to all qualified and
  nonqualified pension and OPEB plans on an aggregate basis. OPEB costs are presented net of the federal subsidy expected for prescription drugs under the Medicare Prescription Drug Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">36</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG contributed $75 million into its qualified pension plans and postretirement healthcare plan in 2008.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note11>Note 11. Income Taxes</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">An analysis of the tax provision expense is as follows:</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%;" >
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD style="width:61.00%;"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:5.73%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:6.01%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:7.66%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:9.60%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center">
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 3.5mm; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      Power</B></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      Other (A)</B></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      Consolidated<br>Total</B></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

    <TD align="center">

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:4mm 0 0.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><hr noshade="noshade" color="k" align="left" style="width:4.00pc; height:0.50pt;;"></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 -8.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      (A)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      PSEG&#146;s other activities include amounts applicable to PSEG (as parent corporation) that primarily relate to financing and certain administrative and general costs and amounts applicable to Energy Holdings that reflect interim period distortion due to asset sales and other one-time adjustments.</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Each of PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G provide deferred taxes at the enacted statutory tax rate for all temporary differences between the financial statement carrying amounts and the tax bases of existing assets and liabilities irrespective of the treatment for rate-making purposes. Management believes that it is
  probable that the accumulated tax benefits that previously have been treated as a flow-through item to PSE&amp;G customers will be recovered from PSE&amp;G&#146;s customers in the future. Accordingly, an offsetting Regulatory Asset was established. As of September 30, 2008, PSE&amp;G had a Regulatory Asset of $418 million
  representing the tax costs expected to be recovered through rates based upon established regulatory practices, which permit recovery of current taxes payable. This amount was determined using the enacted federal income tax rate of 35% and state income tax rate of 9%.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG and its subsidiaries adopted FIN 48 effective January 1, 2007, which prescribes a model for how a company should recognize, measure, present and disclose in its financial statements uncertain tax positions that it has taken or expects to take on a tax return.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">38</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On December 17, 2007 and September 15, 2008, PSEG made tax deposits with the IRS in the amount of $100 million and $80 million, respectively, to defray interest costs associated with disputed tax assessments associated with certain lease investments (see Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities).
  The $180 million of deposits are fully refundable and are recorded as a reduction to the Unrecognized Tax Benefit liability on PSEG&#146;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">It is reasonably possible that the total unrecognized tax benefits (including interest) at PSEG will decrease by approximately $29 million within the next 12 months due to either agreement with various taxing authorities upon audit or the expiration of the Statute of Limitations. This amount includes a $9
  decrease for Power, a $22 million increase for PSE&amp;G, a $24 million decrease for Services, a $23 million decrease for Energy Holdings and a $5 million increase for PSEG parent.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As a result of a change in accounting method for the capitalization of indirect costs, during the first nine months of 2008, PSEG reduced the net amount of its unrecognized tax benefits (including interest) by $86 million, approximately $45 million of which related to PSE&amp;G. Because the IRS agreed with PSE&amp;G&#146;s
  change in accounting method, it is reasonably possible that PSE&amp;G&#146;s claim related to this matter will be settled with the IRS in the next 12 months, resulting in an increase in the unrecognized tax benefits.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note12>Note 12. Financial Information by Business Segments</a></B></FONT></P>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:4mm 0 0.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><hr noshade="noshade" color="k" align="left" style="width:4.00pc; height:0.50pt;;"></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 -8.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      (A)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      PSEG&#146;s other activities include amounts applicable to PSEG (as parent corporation) and Energy Holdings (as parent company) and EGDC and intercompany eliminations, primarily relating to intercompany transactions between Power and PSE&amp;G. No gains or losses are recorded on any intercompany
      transactions; rather, all intercompany transactions are at cost or, in the case of the BGS and BGSS contracts between Power and PSE&amp;G, at rates prescribed by the BPU. For a further discussion of the intercompany transactions between Power and PSE&amp;G, see Note 14. Related-Party Transactions. The net losses
      primarily relate to financing and certain administrative and general costs at PSEG, as parent corporation.</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note13>Note 13. Fair Value Measurements</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 6.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Effective January 1, 2008, PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G adopted SFAS 157 except for non-financial assets and liabilities as described in FSP FAS 157-2 and discussed in Note 2. Recent Accounting Standards. SFAS 157 defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value and expands disclosures
  about fair value measurements. Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. SFAS 157 emphasizes that fair value is a market-based measurement, not an entity-specific measurement, and
  establishes a fair value hierarchy that distinguishes between assumptions based on market data obtained from independent sources and those based on an entity&#146;s own assumptions. The hierarchy prioritizes the inputs to fair value measurement into three levels:</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Level 1&#151;measurements utilize quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G have the ability to access. These consist primarily of listed equity securities, exchange traded derivatives and certain U.S. government treasury securities.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Level 2&#151;measurements include quoted prices for similar assets and liabilities in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in markets that are not active, and other observable inputs such as interest rates and yield curves that are observable at commonly quoted intervals. These
  consist primarily of non-exchange traded derivatives such as forward contracts or options and most fixed income securities.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Level 3&#151;measurements use unobservable inputs for assets or liabilities, are based on the best information available and might include an entity&#146;s own data. In some valuations, the inputs used may fall into different levels of the hierarchy. In these cases, the financial instrument&#146;s level within the fair value
  hierarchy is based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement. These consist mainly of various FTRs, other longer term capacity and transportation contracts and certain commingled securities.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">40</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In addition to establishing a measurement framework, SFAS 157 nullifies the guidance of EITF 02-3, &#147;Issues Involved in Accounting for Derivative Contracts Held for Trading Purposes and Contracts Involved in Energy Trading and Risk Management Activities,&#148; which did not allow an entity to recognize an
  unrealized gain or loss at the inception of a derivative instrument unless the fair value of that instrument was obtained from a quoted market price in an active market or was otherwise evidenced by comparison to other observable current market transactions or based on a valuation technique incorporating
  observable market data. Under EITF 02-3, PSEG Texas had a deferred inception loss of $34 million, pre-tax, as of December 31, 2007 related to a five-year capacity contract at its generation facilities, which was being amortized at $11 million per year through 2010. In accordance with the provisions of SFAS 157,
  PSEG Texas recorded a cumulative effect adjustment of $22 million after-tax to January 1, 2008 Retained Earnings in its Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet associated with the implementation of SFAS 157.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The following table presents information about PSEG&#146;s, Power&#146;s, and PSE&amp;G&#146;s respective assets and (liabilities) measured at fair value on a recurring basis at September 30, 2008, including the fair value measurements and the levels of inputs used in determining those fair values. Amounts shown for PSEG
  include the amounts shown for Power and PSE&amp;G.</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%;" >

    <TD>
    <P style="text-indent:-3.2mm; margin:0 0 0 3.2mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.5mm; "><B><I>Liabilities:</I></B></FONT></P></TD>

       )</FONT></P></TD>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:4mm 0 0.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><hr noshade="noshade" color="k" align="left" style="width:4.00pc; height:0.50pt;;"></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 -8.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      (A)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      Whenever possible, fair values for energy contracts are obtained from quoted market sources in active markets. When this pricing is unavailable, contracts are valued using broker or dealer quotes or auction prices. For contracts where no observable market exists, modeling techniques are employed using
      assumptions reflective of current market rates, yield curves and forward prices, as applicable, to interpolate certain prices.</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">41</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:0.5mm; ">

  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">(B)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Other commodity contracts primarily include more complex agreements for which limited pricing information is available. These contracts are valued using modeling techniques and assumptions reflective of contractual terms, current market rates, forward price curves, discount rates and risk factors, as
      applicable.</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">(C)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Interest rate swaps are valued using quoted prices on commonly quoted intervals, which are interpolated for periods different than the quoted intervals, as inputs to a market valuation model. Market inputs can generally be verified and model selection does not involve significant management judgment.</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">(D)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The NDT Funds and the Rabbi Trusts maintain investments in various equity and fixed income securities classified as &#147;available for sale&#148; under SFAS No. 115, &#147;Accounting for Certain Investments in Debt and Equity Securities.&#148; These securities are valued using quoted market prices, broker or dealer
      quotations, or alternative pricing sources with reasonable levels of price transparency. All fair value measurements for the fund securities are provided by the trustees of these funds. Most equity securities are priced utilizing the principal market close price or in some cases midpoint, bid or ask price (primarily
      Level 1). Fixed income securities are priced using an evaluated pricing approach or the most recent exchange or quoted bid (primarily Level 2). Short-term investments are valued based upon internal matrices using observable market prices or market parameters such as time-to-maturity, coupon rate, quality
      rating and current yield (primarily Level 2). Certain commingled cash equivalents included in temporary investment funds are measured with significant unobservable inputs and internal assumptions (primarily Level 3). The NDT Funds exclude net receivables/payables of $82 million related to pending security
      sales/purchases.</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">(E)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Other long-term investments consist of equity securities and are valued using a market based approach based on quoted market prices.</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">(F)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Cash collateral netting represents collateral amounts netted against derivative assets and liabilities as permitted under FIN 39-1. For further discussion, see Note 2. Recent Accounting Standards.</FONT></P>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
       (1</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">

    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>

       5</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
  </TR>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:4mm 0 0.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><hr noshade="noshade" color="k" align="left" style="width:4.00pc; height:0.50pt;;"></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 -8.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      (A)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      PSEG&#146;s gains and losses are mainly attributable to changes in derivative assets and liabilities of which $26 million is included in Operating Revenues and $(11) million is included in Other Comprehensive Income. Of the $26 million in Operating Revenues, $14 million (unrealized) is at PSEG Texas and $12
      million (unrealized) is at Power. The $(11) million included in Other Comprehensive Income is at Power.</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">(B)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Mainly includes losses on PSE&amp;G&#146;s derivative contracts that are not included in either earnings or Other Comprehensive Income, as they are deferred as a Regulatory Asset and are expected to be recovered from PSE&amp;G&#146;s customers.</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">(C)</FONT></P></TD>

    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG&#146;s gains and losses are mainly attributable to changes in derivative assets and liabilities of which $76 million is included in Operating Revenues and $(3) million is included in Other Comprehensive Income. Of the $76 million in Operating Revenues, $33 million (unrealized) is at PSEG Texas and $43
      million (unrealized) is at Power. The $(3) million included in Other Comprehensive Income is at Power.</FONT></P>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>


<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of September 30, 2008, PSEG carried approximately $1.1 billion of net assets that are measured at fair value on a recurring basis, of which approximately $130 million were measured using unobservable inputs and classified as level 3 within the fair value hierarchy. These Level 3 net assets represent less than
  1% of PSEG&#146;s total assets and there were no significant transfers in or out of Level 3 during the nine months ended September 30, 2008.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=note14>Note 14. Related-Party Transactions</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The majority of the following discussion relates to intercompany transactions. These transactions were properly recognized on each company&#146;s stand-alone financial statements and were eliminated during the consolidation process in accordance with GAAP when preparing PSEG&#146;s Condensed Consolidated
  Financial Statements.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>BGS and BGSS Contracts</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.9mm 0 0 6.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power and PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G has entered into a requirements contract with Power under which Power provides the gas supply services needed to meet PSE&amp;G&#146;s BGSS and other contractual requirements through March 2012 and year-to-year thereafter.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">43</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power has also entered into contracts to supply energy, capacity and ancillary services to PSE&amp;G through the BGS auction process.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The amounts which Power charged to PSE&amp;G for BGS and BGSS are presented below:</FONT></P>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of September 30, 2008 and December 31, 2007, Power had net receivables from PSE&amp;G of $215 million and $451 million, respectively, primarily related to the BGS and BGSS contracts.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In addition, as of September 30, 2008 and December 31, 2007, PSE&amp;G had a payable to Power of $164 million and $55 million, respectively, related to gas supply hedges Power entered into for BGSS.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Services</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.9mm 0 0 6.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power and PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Services provides and bills administrative services to Power and PSE&amp;G. In addition, Power and PSE&amp;G have other payables to Services, including amounts related to certain common costs, such as pension and OPEB costs, which Services pays on behalf of each of the operating companies.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The billings for administrative services and payables are presented below:</FONT></P>

<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Affiliate Loans and Advances</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.9mm 0 0 6.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG and Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of September 30, 2008 and December 31, 2007, Power had a demand note payable of $168 million and $238 million, respectively, to PSEG for short-term funding needs.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.9mm 0 0 6.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G and Services</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of each of September 30, 2008 and December 31, 2007, PSE&amp;G had advanced working capital to Services of $33 million. This amount is included in Other Noncurrent Assets on PSE&amp;G&#146;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.9mm 0 0 6.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power and Services</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of each of September 30, 2008 and December 31, 2007, Power had advanced working capital to Services of $17 million. This amount is included in Other Noncurrent Assets on Power&#146;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Other</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.9mm 0 0 6.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG and Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of September 30, 2008, Power had a net payable to PSEG of less than $1 million. As of December 31, 2007, Power had a net payable to PSEG of $5 million related to amounts that PSEG had paid to suppliers on Power&#146;s behalf.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.9mm 0 0 6.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG and PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of September 30, 2008 and December 31, 2007, PSE&amp;G had net receivables from PSEG of $2 million and $11 million, respectively, related to amounts that PSEG had collected on PSE&amp;G&#146;s behalf.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">45</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>(UNAUDITED)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=Note15>Note 15. Guarantees of Debt</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Each series of Power&#146;s Senior Notes, Pollution Control Notes and revolving Letters of Credit are fully and unconditionally and jointly and severally guaranteed by Fossil, Nuclear and ER&amp;T. The following table presents condensed financial information for the guarantor subsidiaries, as well as Power&#146;s non-
  guarantor subsidiaries.</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%;" >
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD style="width:48.62%;"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:4.97%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:8.68%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>

<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">48</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<PAGE>

<P align="center" style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=item2>ITEM 2. MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL<br>CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS (MD&amp;A)</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">This combined MD&amp;A is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), PSEG Power LLC (Power) and Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. Power and PSE&amp;G
  each make representations only as to itself and make no representations whatsoever as to any other company.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The following discussion relates to the markets in which PSEG and its subsidiaries compete, the corporate strategy for the conduct of PSEG&#146;s businesses within these markets, significant events that have occurred during 2008 and the future outlook for Power, PSE&amp;G and PSEG Energy Holdings L.L.C. (Energy
  Holdings), as well as the key factors that will drive the future performance of these businesses. This discussion includes significant changes in or additions to information reported in the 2007 Annual Report on Form 10-K and refers to the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Statements) and the related
  Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes). This information should be read in conjunction with such Statements, Notes and the 2007 Annual Report on Form 10-K.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG&#146;s business consists of four reportable segments, which are Power, PSE&amp;G and the two direct subsidiaries of Energy Holdings: PSEG Global L.L.C. (Global) and PSEG Resources L.L.C. (Resources).</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power is an electric generation and wholesale energy marketing and trading company that is focused on generation markets in the Northeast and Mid Atlantic U.S. Through its subsidiaries, Power seeks to produce low-cost energy through efficient operations of its nuclear, coal and gas-fired generation facilities.
  Power seeks to balance this generation production with its fuel requirements and supply obligations through energy portfolio management. In addition to the electric generation business, Power&#146;s revenues also include gas supply sales under the Basic Gas Supply Service (BGSS) contract with PSE&amp;G and to other
  customers.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G operates as an electric and gas public utility in New Jersey under cost-based regulation by the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU) for its distribution operations and under regulation by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) for its electric transmission and wholesale sales
  operations. Consequently, the earnings of PSE&amp;G are largely determined by the regulation of its rates by those agencies.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Global</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Domestically, Global owns two 1,000 MW combined cycle generation facilities in the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT) market, and has investments in power producers that own and operate electric generation in California and Hawaii, with smaller investments in New Hampshire and
  Pennsylvania. Global has reduced its international risk by monetizing most of its international investments. Global is also pursuing the development of renewable energy projects.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Resources</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Resources primarily has invested in energy-related leveraged leases. Resources is focused on maintaining its current investment portfolio and does not expect to make any new investments.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">49</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Overview of 2008</B></FONT></P>

<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The results for PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2008 and 2007 are presented below:</FONT></P>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:4mm 0 0.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><hr noshade="noshade" color="k" align="left" style="width:4.00pc; height:0.50pt;;"></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 -8.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      (A)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      In the second quarter of 2008, Resources recorded after-tax charges of $490 million related to the disallowance of deductions taken in prior years&#146; tax filings associated with certain types of leveraged lease transactions. See Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities for additional information.</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:22pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">(B)</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Other activities include non-segment amounts of PSEG (as parent company) and its subsidiaries and intercompany eliminations. Specific amounts include interest on certain financing transactions and certain administrative and general expenses at PSEG and Energy Holdings (as parent companies).</FONT></P>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The quarter-over-quarter decrease in PSEG&#146;s Income from Continuing Operations principally reflected decreases at Power and PSE&amp;G. Power&#146;s Operating Revenues increased due to higher sales prices on re-contracted BGS contracts and in PJM, exceeding the increase in its generation costs that primarily
  resulted from increased prices for natural gas purchases. However, these favorable results were more than offset by higher losses recognized in 2008 on certain securities in the Nuclear Decommissioning Trust (NDT) Funds and higher Operation and Maintenance Costs related to outages at certain facilities of PSEG
  Fossil LLC (Fossil) and PSEG Nuclear LLC (Nuclear). PSE&amp;G&#146;s decrease was principally due to lower sales and higher depreciation. The quarter-over-quarter increase in PSEG&#146;s Net Income was primarily due to the gain of $187 million recognized in 2008 on the sale of the SAESA Group, which was included in
  Income from Discontinued Operations.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The nine month over nine month decrease in PSEG&#146;s Income from Continuing Operations reflected a significant decrease at Resources, largely due to after-tax charges of $490 million recorded in June 2008 associated with deductions taken for tax purposes on certain types of leveraged lease transactions that
  are being challenged by the IRS. See Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities for additional information. Earnings were also slightly lower at PSE&amp;G due to lower sales and higher depreciation. These decreases were somewhat offset by improved earnings at Power and to a lesser degree at Global. Power&#146;s
  Operating Revenues increased due to higher prices and higher sales volumes, partially offset by higher generation costs as well as higher losses in the NDT Fund and Operation and Maintenance Costs. Global&#146;s earnings increased primarily due to improved operations and higher mark to market (MTM) gains at its
  Texas generation facilities.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">50</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Business Developments</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">First Quarter</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG&#146;s Board of Directors approved a two-for-one stock split of PSEG&#146;s outstanding shares of common stock.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The BPU approved the results of New Jersey&#146;s annual BGS-Fixed Price (FP) and BGS-Commercial and Industrial Energy Price auctions and PSE&amp;G successfully secured contracts to provide the anticipated electricity requirements for its customers. As a result of the February 2008 auction, new BGS-FP rates
  increased the average residential customer&#146;s bill by approximately 12% effective June 2008.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">FERC approved the classification of new 69 kV facilities as transmission rather than distribution which PSE&amp;G expects to result in improvements in reliability and more expeditious rate treatment for these facilities.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The U.S. Department of Treasury issued final regulations regarding Investment Tax Credit (ITC) normalization, referring to deferred tax balances that were to be refunded to utility customers but were terminated upon New Jersey&#146;s electric industry deregulation in 1999. The ruling confirmed that none of the
  generation-related ITC could be passed to utility customers without violating the normalization rules.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">Second Quarter</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The U.S. Supreme Court granted the request of industry petitioners, including Power, to review the question of whether Section 316(b) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act allows the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to compare costs with benefits in determining the &#147;best technology
  available&#148; for minimizing adverse environmental impact at cooling water intake structures. This matter could have a material impact on Power&#146;s ability to renew Clean Water Act permits at a number of its larger plants without making significant equipment upgrades involving material expenditures.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The BPU approved a settlement agreement allowing PSE&amp;G to invest approximately $105 million in a solar energy pilot program designed to spur investment in solar power in New Jersey and meet energy goals under the EMP. PSE&amp;G will provide loans to customers in its electric service territory for the
  installation of solar photovoltaic systems on the customers&#146; premises. The program is open to commercial, industrial and residential customers. As of September 30, 2008, PSE&amp;G has received applications for approximately 34% of the 30 MW program.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">FERC approved incentive rate treatment for PSE&amp;G&#146;s Susquehanna-Roseland transmission line project, which will enable PSE&amp;G to earn an adequate return on investment, full recovery of construction costs and the authority to transfer certain incentives to affiliates that are members of Regional Transmission
  Organizations (RTOs).</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">A complaint was filed with FERC with respect to PJM&#146;s Reliability Pricing Model (RPM) on the grounds that the capacity prices set in the first three RPM auctions were not just and reasonable. In September 2008, the FERC issued an order dismissing this complaint. If upheld on rehearing and on appeal, this
  order eliminates the potential for the payment of refunds with respect to transitional auction payments made to generators in PJM, including Power.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G submitted a request to the BPU for an increase in annual BGSS revenues of $376 million to be effective October 1, 2008, representing approximately a 20% increase on a typical residential gas customer&#146;s bill. This request was revised to $267 million on August 27, 2008 and approved by the BPU on
  October 3, 2008.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power completed turbine replacement projects at Hope Creek and Salem Unit 2, increasing its nuclear generating capacity at those facilities.</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:1.67pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">
      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>
      Hope Creek</B>&#151;Phase I increased the nominal capacity of the unit by 10 MW in 2005. Phase II added approximately 150 MW of nominal capacity in the second quarter of 2008.</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Salem Unit 2</B>&#151;Phase I increased Power&#146;s share of the nominal capacity by 14 MW in 2003. Phase II was completed and put in operation in the second quarter of 2008, concurrent with steam generator replacement and increased Power&#146;s share of the nominal capacity by approximately 23 MW.</FONT></P>
    <P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In June 2008, as a result of the recent court decisions regarding certain types of leveraged lease transactions, PSEG evaluated its unrecognized tax benefits under FIN 48, &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">51</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Income Taxes&#151;an Interpretation of FASB Statement 109&#148; (FIN 48), and recorded an after-tax increase to the interest reserve of $135 million in the second quarter of 2008. This charge is recorded in Income Tax Expense in PSEG&#146;s Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations. PSEG also recorded a charge of
  $355 million under FSP 13-2, &#147;Accounting for a Change or Projected Change in the Timing of Cash Flows Relating to Income Taxes Generated by a Leveraged Lease Transaction.&#148; This charge is reflected as a reduction in Operating Revenues of $485 million with a partially offsetting reduction in Income Tax
  Expense of $130 million in PSEG&#146;s Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations. As the tax benefits associated with these lease transactions are timing differences, total cash flows and net income in a leveraged lease transaction remain the same after a change in the timing of the cash flows. The charges
  related to FSP 13-2 will therefore be recognized as income over the remaining terms of the affected leases.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I> <u style="border-bottom: 0.50pt black;">Third Quarter</u></I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In July 2008, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with FERC to implement a cost-of-service formula rate for its existing and future transmission investment. On September 30, 2008, the FERC approved PSE&amp;G&#146;s request for formula transmission rates, effective October 1, 2008. Under this formula, PSE&amp;G will put rates into
  effect in January of each year based upon its internal forecast of annual expenses and capital expenditures, and rates will be trued up to reflect actual annual expenses/capital expenditures in the following year. The order provides for an ROE of 11.68% on existing and new transmission investment.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR), enacted by the EPA in 2005, would have required 28 eastern states to reduce nitrogen oxide (NO</FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:2.5mm; "><SUB>x</SUB></FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">) and sulfur dioxide (SO</FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:2.5mm; "><SUB>2</SUB></FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">) in the 2009, 2010 and 2015 timeframe. In July 2008, CAIR was vacated by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
  Circuit. Subsequent to that ruling, market prices for SO</FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:2.5mm; "><SUB>2</SUB></FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "> allowances have declined significantly, and a decline in electricity prices in certain states has occurred. In September 2008, the EPA, certain industry groups and certain environmental groups filed a petition for rehearing with the Court. By order dated
  October 21, 2008 the Court requested additional briefings from various aligned petitioners, by November 5, 2008, directing them to address:</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:1.67pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">
      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      whether any party is seeking the repeal of CAIR, and</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">whether the Court should stay its mandate to vacate CAIR until EPA promulgates a revised rule.</FONT></P>
    <P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Any significant decrease in electricity prices could adversely affect Power&#146;s revenues. PSEG and Power cannot predict the ultimate resolution of CAIR, nor the ultimate effect on their results of operations. Power foresees no change in its existing construction response to controlling NO</FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:2.5mm; "><SUB>x</SUB></FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "> and SO</FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:2.5mm; "><SUB>2</SUB></FONT><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The Board of Directors of PSEG authorized the repurchase of up to $750 million of PSEG Common Stock to be executed over 18 months beginning August 1, 2008. PSEG is not obligated to acquire any specific number of shares and may suspend or terminate its share repurchases at any time. The amount and
  timing of any stock repurchases would be based on various factors such as management&#146;s assessment of PSEG&#146;s capital structure and liquidity, the market price of PSEG&#146;s common stock and the opportunity to grow the business if investments are available. As of September 30, 2008, approximately two million
  common shares were repurchased at a cost of $92 million. See Liquidity and Capital Resources for more information.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Global closed on the sale of its investment in the SAESA Group for a total purchase price of $1.3 billion, including the assumption of $413 million of the consolidated debt of the group. The sale resulted in an after-tax gain of $187 million. Net cash proceeds, after Chilean and U.S. taxes of $275 million, were
  $600 million.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In August 2008, Global entered into an agreement to sell its 85% ownership interest in Bioenergie, which consists of generation facilities in Italy. The sale is pending. Bioenergie&#146;s operating results for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2008 include a pre-tax impairment charge of $33 million and
  related tax benefits of $22 million which are included in Discontinued Operations.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008, which was passed in October 2008, provides for:</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:1.67pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">

      an eight year extension of the tax credits for solar and other renewable energy sources</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">removal of the $2,000 limit on residential solar credits</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>

    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>

    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>

    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">utility eligibility for the 30% solar credit</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:3.8mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
